div.head:
the first Embleme. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Wine carres him in his belly

lg.l: If Boreas onto expand his windy wombe,
That th' Infant in the world alive may come,
His prowesse will the Heroes all outlive
In art, in hand, in mind, and body too.
Thinke him noe Caeso, nor abortive brood,
Nor yet Agrippa, for his starre was good.

div.head: Discourse 1.
div.ab:
Hermes the most industrious inquisitor into every naturall secret doth
in his Smaragdine table elegantly, though concisely, describe the naturalle
worke, where amongst other things hee sayth: the wind carrys him in his
belly: as if hee should say, Hee, whose father is Sol, and mother Luna,
must, before hee can be brought to light, be carryed by windy fumes, even
as a bird is caryed by the aire, when it flyes: now from fumes or winds, (which
are nothing els but aire moves) coagulated is produced water, from which mixed
with earth doe proceed all mineralls and metalls: yea these very things are
determined to consist and be imediately coagulates of fumes: whether
therefore it be ascribed to water or fume, the thing is the same, because
they are both the matter of wind: the same may be sayd of mineralls
and metalls, though more remotely: now the question is, who hee is, what
ought to be carryd by wind! I answer, Chymically, it is Sulphur, which is
carryd in Argent vive, as Lully in his booke, Chapt 32 attest, and alle the Lully there.
The wind carryd
him in his belly, that
is, Sulphur is carryd
in . and Chap. 47
The Stone is fire
carryd in the belly
of aire
rest: physically, it is an infant, which ought in a little time to be borne into
the world: I say allso Arithmetically, that it is the root of a Cube; Musically,
that it is the Disdiapason; Geometrically, that it is a punctum the begining
of a running line; Astronomically, the center of the planets, Saturne,
Jupiter, and Mars: though these be different subjects, yet if they be
well compard together, they will easily demonstrate the offspring of wind,
which must be left to everymans industry more or lesse. But I indigitate
the matter more plainly thus: every Mercury is compounded of fumes,
that is, of water elevating earth with it into an airy rarity, and of earth
forcing aire to returne into a watry earth or earthy water: for the Ele=
ments being alltogether in it, and mixes, and subdued and reduced together
into a viscous nature, they doe not easily recede one from the other; but
either the volatile doe follow above, or remayne below with the fixes, the
first whereof is evident in comon Mercury, the other in the philosophicall
and fixes metalls: in these the fixes Elements doe predominate the volatile,
in that the volatile oversway the fixes: nor indeed is it without reason, that
Mercury is calld and reputed the mossenger, interpreter, and as it were the
running intermediate minister of the other Gods, with wings fitted to his
head and feet: for hee is windy, and flyes through the aire as wind itselfe,
as is comonly and really confirmes to the damage of many men; but car=
rying a white wand girt with two Serpents crossewise, which can draw soules
out of bodyes, and bring them backe againe, and doe many such contrary
things, hee exquisitely repraesents the philosophicall Mercury. Mercury there=
fore is wind, which takes Sulphur or Dionysius, or, if you had rasher, Ascu
lapius, being yet an imperfect Embryo, out of the mothers belly, or even out
of the ashes of the mothers body burned, and carryes it thither, where it
may be matured; and the Embryo is Sulphur, which is infused into
the belly of Boreas by the caelestialle Sunne, that hee may bring it
forth being matured, who in the compleat time of his cariage produceth
twins, one with white haire, called Calais, the other with red, named
Zethe: these Sonns of Boreas were (as Orphens the Chymicall poet writes)
Discourse 3.
